General economic, political, social and health conditions in the U.S. and abroad affect financial markets and our businesses . Global markets may be affected by the level and volatility of interest rates, availability and market conditions of financing, changes in gross domestic product (GDP), economic growth or its sustainability, inflation, supply chain disruptions, consumer spending, employment levels, labor shortages, wage stagnation, energy prices, home prices, commercial property values .
 Global uncertainties regarding fiscal and monetary policies present economic challenges . High and rising debt levels in the U.S. and globally may contribute to interest rate volatility, which may constrain governments’ fiscal policies, potentially resulting in adverse economic outcomes . Climate change, acute and/or chronic extreme weather events or natural disasters, the emergence of widespread health emergencies or pandemics, cyberattacks, military conflicts, terrorism, or other geopolitical events may also be adversely affected .
 Any increases in policy rates, as a response to inflation persistently above central bank targets, could result in higher market interest rates . Elevated or rising interest rates may continue to result in volatility of equity and other markets . Any future change in monetary policy by the Federal Reserve, in an effort to stimulate the economy or otherwise, resulting in lower interest rates would typically result in lower net interest income .
 High and rising federal debt levels could lead to lower investor appetite for U.S. debt securities, higher interest rates and financial market volatility . Higher interest rates have generally had a positive impact on our net interest income, they have negatively impacted and could continue to negatively impact investment securities, deposits, loan demand and funding costs .
 Increased market volatility and adverse changes in financial or capital market conditions may increase our market risk . These market risks may adversely affect the value of our securities, including our on- and off-balance sheet securities, trading assets and other financial instruments . The value of assets under management (AUM) and fee income relating to AUM are affected by market risks .
 The value of certain of our assets is sensitive to changes in market interest rates and/or spreads . If interest rates decrease, our results of operations could be negatively impacted . In times of market stress, previously uncorrelated indicators may become correlated . Changes to the relationship between market parameters may limit the effectiveness of our hedging strategies and cause us to incur significant losses .
 We have a large portfolio of financial instruments, including loans and loan commitments, securities financing agreements, asset-backed secured financings, derivative assets and liabilities . If asset values decline, we may incur losses and negative impacts, including to capital and liquidity requirements . Increases in interest rates may cause decreases in residential mortgage loan originations and could impact corporate debt originations .
 Increases in interest rates or changes in spreads could also adversely impact our regulatory liquidity position and requirements . Fair values may be impacted by declining values of the underlying assets or the prices at which observable market transactions occur and the continued availability of these transactions or indices . Sudden declines and volatility in the prices of assets may curtail or eliminate trading activities in these assets, which may make it difficult to sell, hedge or value these assets .
 Liquidity is essential to our businesses . We fund our assets primarily with globally sourced deposits in our bank entities . We rely on certain secured funding sources,  such as repo markets, which are typically short-term and credit-sensitive . We also engage in asset securitization transactions, including with the government-sponsored enterprises (GSEs), to help fund a portion of our consumer lending activities .
 Several of these factors may arise due to circumstances beyond our control, such as general market volatility, disruption, shock or stress, stress in sovereign debt markets, the emergence of widespread health emergencies or pandemics . The impact of these potentially sudden events could include an inability to sell assets or redeem investments, unforeseen outflows of cash, the need to draw on liquidity facilities .
 Our liquidity and cost of funds may be impacted by reputation risk, investor behavior and confidence, debt market disruption, firm specific concerns or prevailing market conditions . Changes to interest rates and our credit spreads occur continuously and may be unpredictable and highly volatile . We may also experience net interest margin compression from offering higher than expected deposit rates in order to attract and maintain deposits .
 Our credit ratings are subject to ongoing review by rating agencies, which consider a number of financial and nonfinancial factors . Rating agencies could adjust our credit ratings at any time and there can be no assurance as to whether or when a downgrade could occur . Any reduction could result in a wider credit spread and negatively affect our access to credit markets .
 Bank of America Corporation is dependent on its subsidiaries for liquidity and may be restricted from transferring funds from subsidiaries . The parent company depends on dividends, distributions, loans and other payments from our bank and nonbank subsidiaries to fund dividend payments on our preferred stock and common stock . Any inability of our subsidiaries to transfer funds,  pay dividends or make payments to us may adversely affect our cash flow, liquidity and financial condition .
 Regulatory action that requires additional liquidity at each of our subsidiaries could impede access to funds we need to pay our obligations or pay dividends . Bank of America Corporation’s liquidity and financial condition, and the ability to pay dividends and obligations, could be adversely affected in the event of a resolution . The company's preferred resolution strategy is a ‘single point of entry’ strategy, whereby only the parent holding company would file for bankruptcy .
 Bank of America Corporation has entered into intercompany arrangements resulting in the contribution of most of its capital and liquidity to key subsidiaries . The FDIC may be appointed receiver to conduct an orderly liquidation, and could invoke the . orderly . liquidation authority, instead of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, if the Secretary of the Treasury makes certain . financial distress and systemic risk determinations .
 If the Corporation is resolved under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or the FDIC’s orderly liquidation authority, third-party creditors of our subsidiaries may receive significant or full recoveries on their claims . Security holders of Bank of America Corporation could face significant or complete losses, such as security holders of the Corporation . Our credit portfolios may be impacted by macroeconomic and market conditions, events and disruptions .
 Recessionary environment and rise in unemployment could adversely impact ability of our consumer and/or commercial borrowers or counterparties to meet their financial obligations . Consumers have been and may continue to be negatively impacted by inflation and higher cost of living, resulting in drawdowns of savings or increases in household debt . Certain sectors also remain at risk as a result of shifts in demand and tight financial and credit conditions .
 If the macroeconomic environment or certain sectors worsen, our credit portfolio, net charge-offs, provision and allowance for credit losses could be adversely impacted . The ability of our borrowers or counterparties to repay their obligations may be impacted by changes in future economic conditions, which in turn could impact the accuracy of our loss forecasts and allowance estimates .
 If economic conditions worsen, impacting our consumer and commercial borrowers, counterparties or underlying collateral, and credit losses are unexpectedly worse, we may increase our provision for credit losses . Concentrations of credit risk may reside in a particular industry, geography, product, asset class, counterparty or within any pool of exposures with a common risk characteristic .
 Credit risk may also be heightened by market risk when collateral held by us cannot be liquidated or is liquidated at prices not sufficient to recover the full amount of the loan or derivatives exposure . Disputes with obligors as to the valuation of collateral could increase with significant market stress, volatility or illiquidity, and we could suffer losses if we are unable to realize the fair value of the collateral .
 Oods, wildfires and hurricanes could negatively impact collateral, the valuations of home or commercial real estate or clients’ ability and/or willingness to pay fees, outstanding loans or afford new products . Uncertain economic or political conditions or policies, such as economic sanctions or increased tariffs, could adversely impact the operating budgets or credit ratings of government entities .
 During 2024, the U.S. housing market continued to be impacted by higher mortgage rates, including 30-year fixed-rate mortgages that more than doubled from 2021 . Higher home prices (in varying degrees among markets) have negatively impacted housing affordability and the demand for many of our products . A deeper downturn in the condition of the . condition of . the U .S . housing market could result in significant write-downs of asset values in several asset classes, notably mortgage-backed securities .
 We are exposed to the risk of non-performance by our clients for which we clear transactions, which may not be covered by available collateral . We are also a member of various CCPs, which results in credit risk exposure to those CCPs . Geopolitical stress in one or more countries could have a negative impact regionally or globally .
 Political and economic interactions between the U.S. and important trading partners, including China, may result in sanctions, further tariff increases or other restrictive actions on cross-border trade, investment and transfer of data and information technology . These risks are especially elevated in emerging markets . Foreign exchange rates against the US dollar remain uncertain and potentially volatile .
 We invest or trade in the securities of corporations and governments located in non-U.S. jurisdictions, including emerging markets . Risks in one nation can limit our opportunities for portfolio growth and negatively affect our operations in other nations, including our U.S.-based operations . Government debt levels raise the risk of volatility, significant valuation changes and political tensions .
 Bank of America is subject to complex and extensive U.S. LRRs, which subject us to costs and risks relating to bribery and corruption, know-your-customer requirements, anti-money laundering, embargo programs and economic sanctions . Non-compliance, including improper implementation, and/or violations could result in an increase in operational and compliance costs, and enforcement actions and civil and criminal penalties .
 The Russia/Ukraine conflict and the conflicts in the Middle East have magnified such risks and resulted in regional instability . Emerging market currency values and monetary policy settings are particularly sensitive to such changes in U.S. monetary policy . Widening regional conflicts resulting in the involvement of neighboring countries and/or North Atlantic Treaty Organization member countries could result in additional economic disruptions, financial market volatility, higher inflation and changes to asset valuations .
 A failure in or breach of our operations or information systems could cause disruptions, adversely impact our businesses, results of operations and financial condition, and cause legal or reputational harm . Short-term or prolonged disruptions to our or our third parties’ critical . operations and adversely affect our results of . operations. operations . Our extensive interactions with, and reliance on, third parties and the financial services industry create additional operational risk .
 Business continuity depends on the security, reliability and adequacy of information systems . Cyberattacks, cyberattacks, aging information systems, new vulnerabilities or defects in key hardware and software are possible . Natural disasters, such as wildfires, tornadoes, hurricanes and floods, could also result from natural disasters, including acute and chronic weather .
 A failure, breach or misuse of information systems could expose us to operational losses, regulatory risk and reputational harm . Our inability to properly introduce, deploy and manage operational or technology changes and continuously alter, improve and automate processes and systems, including related controls, could also result in additional operational, information security and regulatory risk, including from the use of artificial intelligence .
 There can be no assurance that our resiliency, business continuity, technology change and information security response plans will effectively mitigate our operational risks . Backup systems or manual processes may not process data accurately and/or as quickly or effectively as our primary systems, and some data might not be available or backed up . The speed in which we are able to remediate any failure or disruption may vary across jurisdictions .
 We rely on effective access management and the secure collection, processing, maintenance, use, transmission, storage, dissemination and disposition of information in our and our third parties’ information systems . We are subject to cybersecurity incidents, information and security breaches that have and in the future could adversely affect our ability to conduct our operations .
 The proliferation of third-party financial data aggregators and emerging technologies, including AI (such as machine learning and generative AI) and robotics, increases our cybersecurity risks and exposure . Cyberattacks are carried out on a worldwide scale and by a growing number of actors, including organized crime groups, hackers, terrorist organizations, extremist parties, hostile foreign governments and their proxies .
 Our vulnerability increases if we fail to implement controls, processes, policies and other protective measures . We cannot anticipate and detect all threats and incidents . We also face risks relating to the large number of third parties we do business with, such as third parties in the industry . We need to be aware of the risks and challenges we face in dealing with them .
 Bank of America: We must rely on our third parties to adequately detect and promptly report cybersecurity incidents . We are at risk from critical third-party information security and open-source or proprietary software defects and vulnerabilities . The failure of these third parties could adversely affect our ability to report or respond to cybersecurity incidents effectively or timely .
 Information systems or information of one or more financial entities or third parties could adversely impact us and increase the risk of operational failure and loss . Cybersecurity incidents or information or security breaches could persist for an extended period of time prior to detection, and it often takes additional time to determine the scope, extent, amount and type of impact, including the information altered, destroyed, accessed or otherwise compromised .
 We expect to continue to experience such events and impacts ourself and at our third parties with increased frequency and severity due to the evolving threat environment . Future cybersecurity incidents could result in disruption to our day-to-day business activities . Loss of clients and business opportunities could lead to increased risk of fraudulent transactions, losses and claims brought by third parties, violations of applicable privacy, cybersecurity and other LRRs .
 The occurrence of any of the events described above could adversely impact our businesses, results of operations, liquidity and financial condition, and cause reputational harm, whether such events are actual or perceived . Failure to satisfy our obligations as servicer for residential mortgage securitizations, loans owned by other entities and other related losses . We may also have liability for failure by us or a third party to adhere to or perform the required servicing obligation in accordance with the terms of the servicing agreements .
 Changes in the structure of and relationship among the GSEs could adversely impact our business . Foreclosures may result in costs, litigation or losses due to irregularities in the underlying documentation, or if the validity of a foreclosure action is challenged by a borrower or overturned by a court because of errors or deficiencies in the foreclosure process .
 Our risk management framework may not be effective in mitigating risk and reducing potential for losses . We seek to effectively and consistently identify, measure, monitor, report and control the risk types to which we face . Risks also may span across multiple key risk types, including cybersecurity risk, climate risk and risk of loss .
 We are highly regulated and subject to evolving and comprehensive regulation under federal and state laws in the U.S. and the laws of the various foreign jurisdictions in which we operate . Failure to manage evolving risks could result in additional legal, regulatory and reputational risk, losses and adversely affect our results of operations .
 We are also required to file various financial and nonfinancial regulatory reports to comply with LRRs in the jurisdictions in which we operate, which results in additional compliance and operational risk . We continue to adjust our business and operations, legal entity structure, systems, disclosure, policies, procedures, processes, controls and governance, including with regard to capital and liquidity management .
 If these assumptions prove incorrect, we could be subject to increased regulatory, legal and compliance risks and costs, and potential reputational harm . Regulators’ prudential and supervisory authority gives them broad power and discretion to direct our actions . We are also subject to LRRs in the U.S. and abroad, including the GDPR and CCPA .
 There remains complexity and uncertainty regarding data transfer because of concerns over compliance with LRRs for cross-border flows and transfers of personal data from the European Economic Area (EEA) to the U.S. and other jurisdictions outside of the EEA . Other jurisdictions, including China and India, have commenced consultation efforts or enacted new legislation .
 Our responses to regulators and other government authorities have been and may continue to be time-consuming and expensive . The outcome of any matter, which may last years, may be difficult to predict or estimate . We could be required to enter into further settlements, orders or agreements and pay additional fines, penalties or judgments, or accept material regulatory restrictions on our businesses .
 The complexity of the regulatory and enforcement regimes in the U.S. and global scope of our operations may give rise to overlapping investigations and regulatory proceedings . Actions by other members of the financial services industry related to business activities in which we participate may result in investigations by regulators or other government authorities . Future legislative or regulatory actions could result in a significant loss of revenue, impose additional compliance and other costs .
 We face significant legal risks in our business, with a high volume of claims against us and other financial institutions . The amount of damages, penalties and fines that private litigants, including clients and other counterparties, and regulators seek from us . We are subject to significant financial and reputational risks from potential liability arising from lawsuits .
 The ultimate resolution of regulatory inquiries, investigations and other proceedings which we are subject to from time-to-time is difficult to predict . Such claims may carry significant penalties, restitution and, in certain cases, treble damages . We are the subject of litigation regarding our processing of electronic payments through the Zelle network, Bank of America .
 Cybersecurity incidents and emerging technologies have resulted in, and will likely continue, related litigation or government enforcement . Misconduct, or the perception of misconduct, by our employees and representatives, could result in further litigation and/or government investigations and enforcement actions . We expect to also face increasing scrutiny regarding sustainability-related policies, goals, targets and disclosure .
 Lawsuits and regulatory actions have resulted in and will likely continue to result in judgments, orders, settlements, penalties and fines . Litigation and investigation costs, substantial legal liability or significant regulatory or government action against us could adversely affect our businesses, financial condition, including liquidity, and results of operations . We are subject to U.S. capital and liquidity regulations .
 From time to time regulators may change regulatory capital requirements, including total loss-absorbing capacity (TLAC) and long-term debt requirements, change how regulatory capital or RWA is calculated, or increase liquidity requirements . These components of our capital and liquidity ratios could also be impacted by economic disruptions or other events that may cause an increase in our balance sheet, RWA or leverage exposures .
 Bank of America's G-SIB surcharge is expected to increase to 3.5 percent from 3.0 percent in 2027 . The Federal Reserve could also limit or prohibit capital actions (e.g., impacts to dividends and common stock repurchases) Changes in accounting standards or assumptions in applying accounting policies could adversely affect us .
 If assumptions, estimates or judgments are erroneously applied, we could be required to correct and restate prior-period financial statements . Accounting standard-setters and those who interpret the accounting standards may also amend or reverse their previous interpretations or positions on how various standards should be applied . U.S. and foreign tax laws are complex and our judgments, interpretations or applications of such tax laws could differ from that of the relevant governmental authority .
 Our ability to attract and retain clients, investors and employees is impacted by our reputation . Harm to our reputation can arise from various sources, including actual or perceived activities of our officers, directors, employees, other representatives, clients and third parties, including counterparties . Adverse developments with respect to tax laws or to other material factors could lead our management to reassess and/or change its current conclusion that no valuation allowance is necessary .
 Our reputation may also be harmed by actual or perceived failure to deliver the products, standards of service and quality expected by our clients and the community, including the overstatement or mislabeling of the environmental benefits of our products, services or transactions . Technology changes, compliance failures, technology changes, the implementation, management and use of emerging technologies, including AI, may also harm our reputation .
 We are subject to complex and evolving LRRs and interpretations, including regarding fair lending activity, UDAAP, electronic funds transfers, know-your-customer requirements, data protection and privacy . If personal, confidential or proprietary information of clients in our possession, or in the possession of third parties or financial data aggregators, is mishandled, misused or mismanaged .
 Financial services companies face significant and increasing competition in the financial services industry . The growth of and mergers among traditional financial services companies have increased competitio . There is increasing pressure to provide products and services on more attractive terms, including lower fees, lower cost investment strategies and higher interest rates on deposits, which may impact our ability to effectively compete .
 Emerging technologies and the growth of e-commerce have lowered geographic and monetary barriers of other financial institutions . Increased competition may reduce our market share, net interest margin and revenues from our fee-based products and services . Our success depends on our and our third-party providers’ ability to timely change or adapt our business strategies to rapidly evolving industry standards and consumer preferences .
 Widespread adoption and rapid evolution of, as well as developments in the regulatory landscape relating to emerging technologies, could negatively impact our ability to compete . As new technologies evolve and mature, our businesses and results of operations could be adversely impacted . We may not be as timely or successful in assessing the competitive landscape and developing or introducing new products and services .
 Models are subject to inherent limitations from simplifying assumptions, uncertainty regarding future outcomes . Models may not be sufficiently predictive of future results, such as due to limited or unanticipated market patterns . Models are required to perform end-to-end validation before initial validation, including re-evaluation, and periodic re-visitation .
 Market conditions in recent years have involved unprecedented dislocations and highlight the limitations inherent in using historical data to manage risk . Failure to properly manage data may adversely affect our ability to manage compliance risk and business needs, and result in errors in our operations, reporting and decision-making, and non-compliance with LRRs .
 Climate change and related environmental sustainability matters present short-, medium- and long-term risks . The physical risks include an increase in the frequency and severity of extreme weather events and natural disasters, including floods, wildfires, hurricanes and tornados . Failure to establish and maintain effective, efficient and controlled data management could adversely impact our development of products and client relationships .
 There is also increasing risk related to the transition to a low-carbon economy . Changes in consumer preferences or financial condition of our clients and counterparties could alter our strategic planning and the scope of our existing businesses . Climate change strategies, policies, and disclosures may evolve over time, our ability to achieve our climate-related goals and targets may impact legal and compliance risk and could result in reputational harm .
 Our ability to attract, develop and retain qualified employees is critical to our success, business prospects and competitive position . It is difficult to predict, identify, monitor and effectively mitigate climate-related risks and uncertainties . Competition for qualified personnel is intense from within and outside the financial services industry . Our competitors include global institutions and institutions subject to different compensation and hiring regulations than those imposed on us .
 We must provide market-level compensation to attract and retain qualified personnel . As a large financial and banking institution, we are and may become subject to additional limitations on compensation practices by the Federal Reserve, the OCC, the FDIC and other global regulators, which may not affect our competitors . A substantial portion of compensation paid to many of our employees is equity-based awards based on the value of our common stock .
